summary: Kept locked inside the house by her father, 7-year-old Chloe lives in fear and fascination of the outside world. It's a place where Abnormals are a constant threat -- or so she believes. But when a mysterious stranger offers her a glimpse of what's really happening, Chloe soon learns that the truth isn't so simple -- but the danger is very real.

reviews.content: Amazing movie. Great take on reality super humans. Fantastic build up. Lots of surprises. Satisfying ending. Finally a movie done right.
Excellent! Very original and creative movie. The girl is a great actress.

How did I miss this hidden gem? In an age with recycled science-fiction / fantasy movies that have no real story Freaks stands out as something fresh and novel. Great acting all around and especially from the child actress. Movies with unlikable annoying children will ruin any movie for me so it was awesome to see the casting people chose right this time. Fast-paced, never boring and filled with well written and fleshed out characters.  Freaks even has some seriously funny lines in it. Even though Freaks deals with some serious family themes, it also remembers to not take itself to seriously. More like the sci-fi movies from the the 80s and 90s Freaks will thrill AND make you laugh. I was so pleased to see that all my questions were answered. Unlike modern movies where it is  almost a guarantee that little to none of your questions will be answered!
Watching Freaks I realized why this is the case with modern movies. It's because the writers themselves don't actually know the answers! They have not completed their story and basically have no real story. This is one I am gong to purchase on DVD and study for years. Now if only Hollywood would take a lessonand do the same, maybe movies would stop sucking so bad. But they won't.
I was expecting this to be cheap and that I would have a few laughs at it but this actually turned out to be such a good movie. Watch this movie, you won't believe how good it is.

Really clever and original(ish) concept, well executed barring for the low budget and low quality production, some of the acting was also below standard. I feel with a higher budget and a glosier feel this could have been a really big movie at the time, but there also could be an argument that its low budget feel is part of the appeal in some places.
Keeps you guessing and on the edge of your seat
Fresh and solid.  Yay!
Very fun, very clever.

It's got a limited budget and a mediocre script (the plot isn't particularly original or well-explained), but you only notice the faults with Freaks if you're trying to be critical. Lipovsky/Stein's suburb direction spins atmospheric horror gold out of straw, aided by a haunting soundtrack and a captivating lead performance from Lexy Kolker.
A surprisingly clever film existing somewhere in the middle of the sci-fi-horror spectrum.

Freaks is brilliant. It's got elements of Xmen with the creepy feel of The 6th Sense. 

I've seen reviews where people complain about the pacing. To me, it's perfect. You get information as the main character does. the story builds momentum until you're on the edge of your seat. 

The cinematography, design, lighting, and acting are all phenomenal. SPFX are also great considering the budget. 

If you need to be quickly forcefed a plot, you won't enjoy it. If you like a slow burn that gives you credit as an audience member, you'll love it.
An original superhero movie. A hidden gem.

I gave it a go and I'm glad I did. It was a very entertaining movie and I felt sympathy for the freaks and even rooted out loud for someone's death in one spot, and that's just not something I do.  I kind of hope they've made more or will make more, I haven't looked anything up yet. It's worth watching.

This is a Firestarter rip off for the most part. King's story is far better. Read the book for real entertainment. Bruce Dern is always interesting to watch and all the actors were just fine. Watchable but just not great, especially for a rip off of another story.

Do NOT assume this is just another poorly made, poorly written, poorly plotted, low budget film with an annoying child character. The child character is annoying, though not due to the acting skills of the actor playing her, and not even necessarily because she was written wrong, for all I know, the way she was written may actually pertain to the premise, at least, that's what I think. Anyway, Freaks is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen. Extremely well plotted.

Freaks (2018) is a North American science fiction thriller written and directed by Zach Lipovsky and Adam B. Stein.  The main characters of the film are Chloe aka Eleanor Reed (Lexy Kolker), Chloe's Dad, Henry Lewis (Emile Hirsch), Mr. Snowcone (Bruce Dern), Mary (Amanda Crew),  and Agent Ray (Grace Park).
A sweet and delightful seven year old girl escapes her deranged and disturbed father's clutches who has filled her mind with paranoia and fear, and hops a ride with Mr. Snowcone, the ice cream man, who convinces her to take a ride.  Until she flees the house, Chloe has never been outside her house.  Her father has convinced her that it isn't safe and she would be in mortal danger if she left and that she would be killed.  There is something deeply troubling and disturbing about the father/daughter relationship, and Henry's parenting skills.  Meanwhile, Mr. Snowcone has secretly left Chloe little gifts in an attempt to lure her away.  It's a film where paranoia meets reality seen through the eyes of a child and where an altered reality is juxtaposed with the real.  Is the father really paranoid?  What is his motivation to isolate Chloe from the outside world?  What about Mr. Snowcone?   Is Mr. Snowcone really a good Samaritan?   Is he really an ice cream man?  Why is he so interested in Chloe?  How does he know her name?  Is he a pedophile?  Once out of the house and in Mr. Snowcone's ice cream truck, Chloe's journey begins and boy, is she in for an adventure.  Is she really at risk?  Why does Chloe disobey her father?   The film sets up many intriguing questions whose answers are revealed in the narrative of the film which grows in complexity and madness.
Besides being a science fiction thriller, it's really a coming of age film for a special, precocious little girl who has a mind of her with incredible powers who seeks a normal life and a mommy.  She has many new experiences on her own without her father's interference and becomes her own little person. 
A good film is not without its villains and in Freaks there are several.  The film is situated within a post-modern, out of kilter world, where freaks/the abnormals have disturbed the social order.  The film shocks and there are many disturbing scenes.    The  disturbing behaviour of Chloe's Dad, Mr. Snowcone, the police, Agent Ray, and Chloe herself run as a motif throughout the film stitching it into a cohesive structure.
The directors have woven together many visual elements to create a science fiction thriller that will leave you in suspense as more of Chloe's backstory and that of the main characters are revealed.   The juxtaposition of the real with an altered reality is compelling and adds to the dramatic tension of the film.    If you want to find out what happens to Chloe, then, well, you've got to see the film which is engaging and will hold your attention.
The directors juxtapose Chloe's story against the simmering tensions amongst the characters which fuels the dramatic tension in the film.  Hirsch shines as the disturbed and deranged father with a heart of gold who will do anything to protect his daughter.  Dern is marvelous to watch as Mr. Snowcone who is equally aggressive and abusive towards Chloe who intentions are to use her as a pawn to rescue his own daughter who is being held captive in an underground camp deep within the bowels of a mountain.   Kolker (Chloe), Hirsch and Dern have chemistry and are interesting to watch as they play off each other, together or separately. The piece de la resistance is Kolker who is phenomenal in her role as the precocious seven year old coming into her own. 
The film resonated with me on a personal level posing important philosophical and existential questions such as the importance of minority rights and diversity.   It shines a light on the pathology of a dominant society which will go to extraordinary lengths to rid itself of differences evoking the horrors of Nazi Germany.  It's an intriguing film shining a light on the pathology of ideological thought that fails to consider humanity in all its diversity.  It was a compelling film to watch and, I don't think I'll ever be able look at an ice cream truck in the same way again.
Awesome movie. Great fantasy storie. Genius.
Kept me guessing until the end which was satisfying. Good story. Entertaining throughout.

"FREAKS" Psychological drama or a practice in editing to evoke emotion. So, here we have the age old mental health question, "Am I Being Paranoid, or is it Real?"
Unfortunately you will not get an answer, or maybe we weren't supposed to, you know, the whole "make Us Think" aspect.
The bright spot in this plot identity crisis is Lexy Kolker age 13, and carries this film. There are points in this film that are genius, sadly those moments are so rare, that the effort goes largely un-noticed.

It was tense and I didn't know what was going to happen or who was bad or good.... and for me that makes it a very good movie. A Fantastic FIlm. Bruce Dern is amazing as usual as so is Emile and Lexy's performance. This movie kept me interested all the way and kept me guessing as too what was coming up ahead through the entire movie.
This movie is so underrated. We want a sequel!

Wasn't sure what to make of this from the start and about 30mins in I still wasn't sure it was leading to anything, and I was starting to think is it worth continuing to watch as it starts off being quite disturbing. Wasn't sure if there were bad people outside like aliens or something like that, or if the father was just some psycho creep. But then the story started to come together in a big way and I would say a good way. 
You learn more about each of the "Freaks" special abilities and although it kinda feels like elements of the movie have been done before in other films, it is still very enjoyable to watch as the over development was delivered in a fresh way, I was glued to the screen. 

Some good acting in this little gem especially from the little girl which I thought got better throughout this film. 
I do enjoy watching really good low budget films and I think this film potentially warrants a sequel finale. 
5 Stars from me
Excellent movie . Different great story line and a must see .

just awful. unoriginal, poorly acted by all (including the annoying little angry girl), and simply atrocious writing. really is a rarefied compendium of many of the trends that make a lot of modern sci fi films suck. overwrought emotionally with hamfisted political overtones. ratings here are comically inaccurate.
It only takes 10 minutes or so to overcome its low budget veneer, so give it a chance and you will be justly rewarded.
Good, quite clever. I hope there's a sequel to answer my questions
Wasn't sure what the movie was about but it kept me interested all the way through the end. The ending was spectacular.
Great writing and story, a refreshing change from Marvel popcorn predictability.

Captivating, gripping, enthralling, and all those other buzzwords, but seriously, It's a basically perfect horror/sci-fi movie with everything you could possibly want: stupidly talented actors giving incredible performances and a super tight script serving the viewer an unapologetically twisted experience. So good.

A 7-year-old girl, kept hidden by her father, has the power of making people do what she wants and uses it to rescue her imprisoned and tortured mother, who has other super powers. The girl's father (Emile Hirsch) and grandfather (Bruce Dern) also have unique superpowers. Similar to, but better than, the "X-Men" franchise, normal people label the gifted people "freaks," hunt them down and cull them.
Loved the mysterious beginning that reminded me of both Room and 10 Cloverfield Lane, and then when this movie takes quite a different turn it will remain to enthrall you.

Sci fi audace e ben elaborato; in cui la sceneggiatura è molto ben orchestrata ed inserire costantemente elementi nuovi impreziosendo la trama, proprio nei momenti in cui si teme che lo sviluppo si rallenti.
L'argomento non è particolarmente originale e probabilmente viene lasciato eccessivo spazio alla giovane protagonista, mentre vengono leggermente sacrificati i personaggi di Hirsch e Dern.
Anche il finale è di alta qualità come tutto il film, davvero poche sono le forzature; la più evidente è quella sulla difficoltà nel riconoscere gli "anormali", potendosi affidare solo ad una luce ultravioletta, facilmente sconfiggibile con dell'acqua ossigenata.
This is a great movie!

Unbelievable the amount of sheer ignorance I have had to read in the negative reviews of this absolute masterpiece. This film is creative genius at it's best, using inspiration from many of the best genre media to date to craft together a beautifully moving modern, dystopian fairy tale. The confidence in the direction is next level, as Adam B Stein help bring to life these very believable characters which are not confined to any moral archetypal standards. Their journey feels very personal and their motivations are completely realized, in part due to the magnificent acting of the entire cast. The way in which the film blends and transforms it's genre is another journey in itself, which makes the experience in watching this film one of the best you can hope for. Mainstream American Hollywood can get very hung up on having no grey, moral ambiguity about it's characters. But smaller, independent films such as these prove that the key in making a relatable, enthralling, cinematic presentation is in the overall relatability of the characters and their relationships between each other.

Some on this website have criticized the slow pacing at the beginning of the film. Slow compared to what? The MCU? I myself noted that the film really takes off right around 30mins. How demanding of an audience member do you have to be, to expect to be immediately entertained in a manner in which only you desire, before even 30mins into a feature-length film. Get real. The 1st act is crucial in setting up the world in which Chloe lives in and is told from her perspective so that we can understand her and become invested in her. I guess some people wanted more explosions? The whole plot is very easy to follow and straight-forward. Unless you may have forgotten to take your medication.

And yet another negative review talks about how the restraints of the budget directly affected the effectiveness of the storytelling. What world do we now live in, where slow-motion CGI, extensive practical and visual effects, and elaborate sets, are now just not enough?? Get real! If anything, the lack of multi-million-dollar-5-second-shots simply helps propel the characterizations and gritty writing even more. Is everything now to be compared to the shallow eye-candy thrills of the MCU??

And finally, as if to prove my point, one astute reviewer claims that this is simply an X-men film rip-off. Get freaking real!! As if any story which involves supernatural abilities is copyrighted by Marvel now. Plus, didn't The Boys already prove that there is no monopoly on compelling stories about individuals with superpowers? I tell you the truth, there is more character development and raw emotion in these 105 minutes than in every X-men film combined.

Basically, if your film repertoire expands beyond the pea-sized Marvel Cinematic Universe, you'll at the very least enjoy this film and not regret having experienced it. Take that, Dark Phoenix.
Not a horror. Pretty good action scifi

It took a while for this film to 'take off' for me.  I think this was mostly due to the fact that they were being intentionally opaque about the circumstances for dramatic effect.  Since I like the sci-fi genre I stuck it out and I'm glad I did.  It got more interesting.

What's up with these reviewers? I really do not get how anyone could have enjoyed this. Not only is the story line lame, but it's slow and boring. There's another 1.5 hours I'll never get back.

The film starts off slow and nothing makes sense but when you get to the halfway point the build up starts and it gets good. Whoever played the Dad gave an amazing performance. The concept of the film is pretty naff but somehow it just works. Its a good sci-fi. Definitely a rent it.

One of the worst movies I've ever seen. That's 1 hour and 44 minutes of my life I will never get back. Weak storyline and plot and absolutely no empathy for a spoiled seven year old brat. Nothing was explained or revealed about the "abnormals" Don't waste your time.
This was weird, disconcerting, totally not what I expected and GREAT!
Great characters. Great story

Light spoiler to follow though no plot point: If you want my advice don't read reviews, don't walk, just run to see this movie. I can't possibly do this amazing movie justice with the review. 

I went in looking for a Sci-Fi horror and got more of a darker x-men/superhero action/thriller. It had everything from dark comedy, feels, interesting powers/concepts, and a sort of dystopian feel. By time the end was nearing a friend and I were practically screaming YES at the TV. With a thrilling ride and such a satisfying ending I was left extremely pleased by time the credits rolled. Easily one of the best movies I have ever seen.

A brilliant sci-fi thriller. I didn't watch the trailer, and the Netflix description was just one sentence long, so I really went in having no idea what to expect. Since I had no idea what to expect, I believe it made me more engaged when certain things start happening. I didn't know where it was going at times, but it had a definite sense of direction. I felt like the plot was original and it's one movie I'll definitely be re-watching soon.

The acting was superb, especially Lexy Kolker's performance in which she plays a 7 year old girl whose world is so beyond the norm and she begins to understand this. The cinematography was also excellent. 

If you like sci-fi movies, thriller movies, or a combination of the two, this movie is for you. I thoroughly enjoyed it. All I can say is that you need to see "Freaks".
Amazing movie, I wish there was a sequel
This is a really great movie that I had never heard of until I saw it on Netflix.  Great acting and story!

Great movie, though, the only problem with it is the morally dubiousness of it all.

On one hand, a little girl finally gets to have what she wanted most...
And on the other, events unfold that lead to the deaths of many, with likely so many more to come. 

So it was hard to enjoy the protagonists' plight, despite the creative setting.
It left me speechless...
Very solid plot, the story is internally consistent and manages to keep you on your toes. Acting is superb. Proves you don't need a huge budget to make a great film.

Very good low budget sci-fi mutant style movie.  This is the kind of stuff they could have done with New Mutants.  They made very good use of their budget and focused on the characters and story which went a long way.

If Xmen were real life.  Freaks in this movie are marked as outcasts.  Little Chloe has been hidden from the world, but when she realizes what's going on, she wants to break all the other freaks out of hiding.

Wow. I loved every second of it. It starts with a really interesting mystery plot that then evolves into really good susoense and action scenes.

Blew me away with how good this was.

Very good movie with a very good storyline but doesn't really explain what is happening very well at the start.

My recommendation is to view this terrific film without watching trailers or reading reviews, but since you're here, read on:  Freaks is a brilliant reimagining of the superhero mythos and it's incredible what suspense, mystery, and thrills directing duo Adam Stein and Zach Lipovsky are able to build up inside a small dilapidated building.  Indeed, it may be these directors who display the true superhuman abilities given the film was created on a budget of $2,000 (and lots of favors).  Just compare that to Marvel's latest hundred million dollar budget blockbuster.  And yet Freaks never feels low-budget or small.  Instead the world is intriguing and the superpowers are epic.  Freaks never scales back its vision instead soars beyond its humble origins with its unique and confident storytelling.
Great movie. Definitely worth a watch. So much better than most other movies that were put out in 2020.
took some patience in the first hour and then the movie morphed into an x-men movie that really mattered.

Chloe dreams to one day be outside and play and act like any other normal 7 year olds would. As far as she knows according to her father the world outside their home is a dangerous place to be. The mysteries surrounding why that is a fact escapes Chloe while she struggles to find the truth of their situation. Desperate to be freed of her fathers paranoid controlling nature she decides to seek for this truth on her own terms. Chloe is drawn to a old man who appears in his Ice Cream truck music illuminating the cul-de-sac everyday. One day she sneaks away while her father sleeps and seeks out the source of the music, the old man reveals a shocking revelation that shows that either her father is vastly paranoid over nothing or is there something far more nefarious happening. 

This is one review that i won't indulge too much on a synopsis as i went into this film completely blind after seeing the trailer and heard everlasting good things about this film prior to watching. That mystery going into this film quite honestly makes it that much better. It starts a little slow which just only adds to the conundrum of what you're seeing, stick with it and everything falls right into place nicely for a satisfying conclusion. For such a low budget this film was executed beautifully. In my opinion buckle up for the reveal in the final act, it certainly delivers.

There's a lot going on at once but Freaks is an intriguing and quite original sci-fi drama. With solid performances and impeccable visual effects, the film tells its somewhat unique story in a captivating way.

The story unfolds very nicely and keeps the viewer staring at the screen the whole time; each scene there is something happening, either a particular to grasp (e.g. birds stuck in the sky) or some broader fundamental questions (e.g. is Chloe's father paranoid or is there something else?)

I also liked the way characters superpowers were unvealed and used, it's not the usual bloating of special effects and super hero non-sense.
Watched on a whim and am glad I did. It's like a more dystopian X-Men. Hope they make a sequel/prequel.

I was interested in the synopsis of the film and when I went to watch it, I was not disappointed. The movie is really good, the plot develops slowly, but that doesn't make it bad, on the contrary, it is a way for us to enjoy its development more and for us to have a good experience, the movie is very good and and really worth watching.

So the main character is a 7 year old cutie pie with a penchant for violence. The use of "freak" abilities is measured, despite the characters clearly having awesome power. The violence is sober, without indulgence. I hear it was low budget too - great work. The story itself leaves a little to be desired, but it held together okay (and if you like superpowers, that'll be enough).

The self-inflicting seclusive film expands the living space for "Room" before slowly stirring in different elements that unveils sci-fi and a bit of horror as it unfolds into a familiar, bleaker narrative under elaborative subtexts and incoherent effects, only emotionally standing strong by the genuinely solid performances. (B)

I liked the characters, but I thought the plot was thin.  Told from the perspective of a young girl, we are slowly fed clues about what is going on.  Some unsavory themes here, like killing to survive and stay free.  Normal people are the freaks in this one.
great film. slow builder in to a dramatic end
Keeps you guessing to the very end. Just great, watch it.
I love this movie! Love the cast and everyone that was involved in making this film. Very original and well thought out. I can't wait to see more from you guys!
I loved this movie from beginning to end.  Very original!
Well done and interesting film.
quite alright, not bad story

This was a pretty good movie. I went into it blind, not having seen the trailer, and I was pleasantly surprised. I almost didn't watch it since it was labeled horror and I am a giant ball of nerves!!! However, THIS IS NOT A HORROR MOVIE. So all you fellow wusses out there, feel free to watch. The beginning was hard to get through, I was so over it (partly because I watched most of it through the cracks of my fingers). But once the story began to unravel (and I realized it wasn't horror) it started coming together. The little girl did a great job... her acting coach was NOT cheap! lol  I definitely recommend.
at first I was like mmmh kinda boring. But it actually was a good movie. The second half was so much better.

I am a science-fiction movie fan and this movie is great because like many in the "persecuted superhuman" genre of films it is all about prejudice and hatred. It explores, in cookie-cutter fashion, the lengths that families will go to to protect each other in a world that is committed to destroying them. How would I best describe this movie??? It's a union of the Diary of Anne Frank, X-Men(Persons), and Prison Break. Just imagine if Jean Grey was raised under Nazi Occupation, and had to rescue her mother from Ravensbrück and you've got and Idea of what this movie is like. Her mom is a Bad-ass!! There is some serious GIRL POWER in this film. Check it out!
A waste of my time.  Could not stop nodding off to sleep during the second half of the movie.  Finally gave up watching.
The movie was a poor production. I've wasted soo much time watching it, but couldn't stop but already knew the ending. It was soo predictable.
Solid movie and interesting concept.
Tries to get way too much mileage out of the creepy little girl trope, and barely delivers on its long-promised payoff.
Emotional and powerful, Lexy Kolker plays a commanding and ambitious role.
Felt very much like a TV movie but thought the premise along with the performances were brilliant.
Was unsure where it was going for a bit, but when it takes off my god it takes off! Fantastic film.

Borrowed the DVD from my local library. It's a captivating story and mystery, with very good acting (particularly from the young star), and the right dosage of creepiness. Nice setting and soundtrack as well. After watching the behind-the-scenes bonus feature I appreciated the movie even more.

Captivating from beginning to end as events unfold in the most unexpected of ways.

4 of 5

I came into this movie with no expectations or prior knowledge and honestly loved it. The plot kept me guessing for the first hour which is a welcome change, as it's not often I can't at least work out the general plot from the first half an hour any more. An unexpectedly interesting plot, some great visuals and some amazing performances from all the cast, the dad being a huge highlight for me, his evolution through it being amazing to watch. Would definitely recommend and watch again, and cannot wait to see what the writers and main cast members work on next!
Part firestarter part heroes, interesting  take on what might happen if people really had superpowers.

Good movie, maybe drags a bit too long. 
The kid actress is amazing, I was amazed at her acting skills at only 7/8 years old age.

Freaks wasn't a horror and didn't make for a very good sci-fi as there was practically no world building. The visual effects were low quality, the acting could have been better at times, and the writing was disappointing. All I know after watching the film is that there were superheroes who looked like regular people but who bled from their eyes after using their powers... It's not explained why they bleed from their eyes, the powers felt pretty ridiculous and overpowered, and the mum should have been able to escape alone since she was basically Superwoman. The concept was ok, but most of the film is spent inside a rundown house or in an icecream van. The plot was mostly predictable and very forgettable. At least the cinematography was good, but I've forgotten what the soundtrack was like so it can't have been anything special. The film was so confusing that it did remain somewhat engaging, but it's a below average sci-fi. No idea how it got put in the category of 'horror' as there's nothing scary or disturbing in this film. It's a low budget sci-fi action film with a weird plot.

Solid performances from Bruce Dern and Lexy Kolker (Granpa and Chloe), the psychological elements were well covered. Not so sparkling from realy anyone else in the cast and the first 30 minutes were wasted in setting up the premise and then belabouring it. Some may critisize the lack of SFx though I would suggest there was enough room for the audience to stretch their own imaginations and fill in the gaps. Good all round effort worthy of the original Firestarter (Drew Barrymore) and Carrie (Sissy Spacek).
Finally, an unpredictable sci-fi film!

Zach Lipovsky is clever and ingenious. Freaks is incredibly unpredictable, you never know if Chloe is truly safe and can trust the people in her life, even her Dad and Grandpa. We are always waiting for something to go horribly wrong. I must admit that I am not the biggest Sci-fi fan but the amount of story packed into an hour and 45 minutes is spectacular and gripping to say the least. There is so much to explore in this corrupt modern world, It has no limitations on what could happen next. The role of Chloe (played by Lexy Kolker) is magnificently done! such a young and talented actress deserves to be recognised. She carried her role and the story throughout! There are also brilliantly timed comedic lines spaced throughout the film that give the audience a little bit of balance/ an escape from the terrifying world outside the front door. The whole concept is astounding! Freaks is very smart and well done indeed!

In a time where "super powered being"s are all the rage, you'd think this one would lean into it a little more.

The entire premise is that in a time where having powers is illegal (basically the Super Human Registration act from Marvel), a guy is trying to raise his potentially super powered daughter. But they bury it entirely.

I went in not knowing anything, I think I got a glimpse of some interesting auto-play. And normally that's a great experience, but not building the world premise until the 2nd act shaves a little bit off. Now, that shouldn't spoil anything, it just explains why I thought I got tricked into watching a kidnapping movie for almost the first half.

Once they start opening up and communicating, the movie picks up in the right direction nicely. And the movie is filled with familiar faces: I'm not going to tell you that you'd know their names, but they're all good actors, and a lovely surprise to see Amanda Crew rounding out her acting range in this.

I do want to call out Lexy Kolker (the little girl), who attempted to carry the lead role in this movie, it's her movie (despite being listed 5th on IMDB) who did a great job for her age. However I really feel like it need someone to do an excellent job to make this movie what it could have been. As she's pretty early in her career, I'd say she's one to watch as she grows up in the business.

Freaks delivers as the kind of movie-length, (early) Black-Mirror-like Sci-Fi you need. Its low-budget is a testament to the writing, acting, and plot — how low, I was unable to find, and I cannot believe it was only $2,000. Most importantly, the film keeps you engaged as the plot releases pieces of information that you begin to place into a puzzle to create context. The one-sentence tease on my TV was barely enough for me to click-on it — the Emile Hirsch casting put it on my watch-list. Like all children in dystopian/post-apocalyptic movies, Chloe (Lexy Kolker) can't seem to follow instructions meant to protect her. Unlike (most) children in dystopian/post-apocalyptic movies, Chloe has… powers. The film is only a couple of years old and not well-known, so I'm going to refrain from spoilers, but the concept of the "crazies" or "abnormals" and how to tell them apart from "us", the ADF (think Sci-Fi ICE, but more murdery), and Madoc Mountain — a super-max torture-prison that could be a little more well-guarded — create a futuristic society that doesn't seem too farfetched from where we're headed. Of course, without the superpowers. While it has obvious political messaging, it doesn't come off as preachy, unlike (late) Black Mirror. Freaks is yet another excellent example of indie films doing on a shoe-string budget what studios can't accomplish with truckloads of cash-money.
Superb buildup and solid acting. Some genuine surprises and emotional wrought finish. Well worth an early AM binge.

"Freaks" is a thrilling and compelling mix of dystopia, science-fiction, horror, and coming-of-age drama. This is a film that develops plausibly from a sort of claustrophobic horror-drama into a surprisingly more emotional thriller with grounded characters.

The film is made with parts that are not completely unfamiliar with movie veterans. What makes the film compelling and stand out is its suspenseful direction and the characters. As Roger Ebert once said, "A movie is not about what it's about. It's about how it's about it."

You begin the film thinking that Henry Louis (Emile Hirsh) is a psychopathic creep who is raising a girl named Chloe (Lexy Kolker) who may not even be his own daughter. Their house is ill-kept and boarded up, suggesting perhaps that the house is abandoned or that Henry is a fugitive. If this story had been told from any other perspective, it would have gained a sense of objectivity and omniscience, where there would be no ambiguity about Henry, but the story is framed mostly from young Chloe's perspective, who in her first few years witnesses her father's strange behavior, as well as an old man who runs an ice cream truck, who may know more about the real world than her father is letting on. This is the sort of ambivalence and inner conflict children feel all the time, and so we identify with Chloe, with her built-up curiosities and frustrations--and their consequences. In a way, part of the film is about growing up and how the follies of society magnify the worst in us. 

There are several other subplots and subtexts, some of which I won't mention to avoid spoilers. There are the scenes throughout the movie where Chloe sees visions of a woman in her closet, and visions where she finds herself at a neighbor girl's sleepover party. It's clear that both her visions and how she interacts with them are, at least initially, out of her control and comprehension. Because Chloe lives in an aggressive world where others seem malevolent towards her on principle, poor Chloe does not really stand a chance in growing up well-adjusted. No attempt is made for a peaceful dialogue between Chloe and her enemies, and I think the film may have benefited from explaining why everyone is so uncompromisingly hostile. 

"Freaks" is dark, unpleasant, suspenseful, and poignant. It's good cinema, much more inspiring as a thriller, I think, than "The Invitation" or "It Comes at Night." If you want to feel depressed and sad, this is likely for you.

𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲: A time-warping father and his 7-year-old daughter with mind control are forced to spend years isolated within their home. Belonging to a mutant species identified by society as "Freaks," they would be killed on site if their true identity was to be discovered. 

Fairly ambiguous with lots of intentionally withheld information to reflect the perspective of its 7-year-old protagonist, this film is chaotic and never travels in one direction long enough. The cinematography includes lots of orange light and distorted backgrounds with close up shots that make for a unique viewing. It has a rough first half but picks up a lot once it becomes more comprehensible. A really cool idea, this film falls significantly flat likely due to a combination of a low budget and lack of A-list acting.

In the not so distant future, human evolution takes the next step. Certain people start to develop superhero like powers and are referred to as freaks. They are easy to spot, as often times, after using their powers, they bleed from the eyes. As with anything they don't understand, the government sees these people as a threat and has started to hunt them down. One such family, having recently lost a wife/mother has gone on lock down in a suburban neighborhood, this is their story. After seeing the trailer for this movie I was intrigued, until I realized it was just a rip-off of the X-Men, without the special effects. Basically they promote this thing like it's the next big thing in Science Fiction, when it's just a very old idea that's been done to death. As for the film itself, it takes forever to get going and even longer for you to realize just what the hell is going on. This crazed father is babbling on making no sense and keeping this little girl locked in this house. All she seems to care about is ice cream, more so than the life of her father or her personal safety, the whole thing was just so bizarre. As for the cast, there really wasn't any chemistry, Emile Hirsch was just awful, playing this paranoid babbling idiot. He's paired with Bruce Dern, who is far too old to really do much of anything, and then there's Chole (Lexy Kolker), the little girl stuck in the middle of all it. The bottom line, Freaks is an idea that has been done and done again, with a cast that so vastly different, that really doesn't click on any level. Worst of all it takes so long to get going and explain what's going on. By the time you finally get it, you've really stopped caring. Freaks looked cooled and has a trailer that will suck you in, but ultimately it's a disappointment.

The concept of the movie was great, but as it was unveiled, it was confusing. I would not recommend this as a good use of your time. It appeared to be low-budget in the art department as the final chase scenes in the mountain could have been filmed in a laser tag maze.

Well, this was a bonkers sci-fi thriller that usually I don't go for, but had me from the start thanks to some fantastic writing and performances to match.  So it's a little Room-ish, but for much different reasons.  There are super powers, but there is also a through line that just because you're different you're a freak.  Hence the name of the movie, which at times overplays how harsh the majority is to minorities.  Newcomer Lexy Kolker portrays a seven year old with special powers.  She is a revelation.  Longtimer Bruce Dern as her grandfather and Emile Hirsch as her dad complete a trio that all have a wonderful chemistry.  Dern continues to take projects that are different.  He's marvelous in this.  It's the kind of movie that could catch on and become a cult classic.  Perhaps someday even a sequel.... or a prequel!  Final Score: 8.8/10

It's actually closer to Heroes, but let's not worry about comparisons. What the movie does well is deliver over the timeline. It has to be somewhat annoying at first to really drill into you why this kid behaves this way so she doesn't just come across as a brat with superpowers. And even better is that it doesn't end with a sense that they could have done more. And even better, it's a stand alone film (so far) so it doesn't have the chance to lose momentum over the course of a series or a billion identical sequels. Personally, I think it's a fantastic little package and should stay this way. Good job! Let's see what else they can do without ruining this one. I highly recommend it.

What a pleasant surprise. I rented this one from iTunes for only .99 cents and I went in completely blind without seeing any trailers. I recommend you do the same if you decide to check this one out. A sci-fi, mystery film about a young seven year old girl named Chloe (Lexy Kolker) who lives in a run down house with her dad Henry (Emile Hirsch). Henry is teaching Chloe how to blend in and appear "normal." Henry makes Chloe scared of the outside world telling her that if she's ever to leave the people outside will kill her. Pretty mysterious right? The thing is when Chloe looks outside it appears the world is quite normal. With a craving for ice cream like no other one day Chloe runs outside the house and meets a somewhat creepy ice cream man named Mr. Snowcone (Bruce Dern). Mr. Snowcone drops some knowledge on Chloe and tells her that she's special and that there's much more to what's going in the world than what she really believes. I'm being incredibly vague here because there's a lot to benefit not know the whole story here. I want to avoid spoilers, so I will say this one had some great pacing, a very good plot where you really feel for the characters. The film also is a low budget indie film and it shows, but they make use of the sets quite well here. By the time the movie was done I actually wanted to see more and explore more of this world they show off here. I would definitely recommend checking this one out as I had a lot of fun with it and I think any sci-fi fan will enjoy it!

Can't believe I found out about this movie only now and only by accident. I actually loved it! The beginning is really messy and makes you question what are you even watching, but the confusion plays well into the rest of the story because there is just so much going on and by the end, along with the characters, we find out how all of that mess started. If this would happen in real life, I imagine it would feel just as chaotic and confusing. We have multiple important characters none of whom are perfectly good, but no one is wholly bad which, again, is true in real life most of the time. Although the subject of super powers is explored in hundreds of movies, for me this one did it best. The movie introduces the ultimate dilemma that makes you think about the greater good or the lesser evil in a very personal and painful way, this should be explored further, there is so much material to continue the story and develop characters, it feels like this is just a beginning. I would have loved to read this story in a book, with plenty of details, from a perspective of multiple characters. Excellent acting by the leads and I just have to mention the use of colour throughout the movie, so much work was put into that alone and the result is so satisfying. Amazing work, really hope there will be more of this in the future.

There are a few plot holes and a general sense that there wasn't enough of a budget or time to tell the bigger story properly, but for the most part, ‘Freaks' is a clever and mysterious, character-driven, genre-bending flick that keeps things interesting by only slowly revealing what's actually going on. 

Interestingly, the first half of the film has a very different feel to the second half and that might be its undoing for a lot of people. Personally, I went into this without having seen a trailer or really knowing anything about it and found myself pleasantly surprised.

When I first heard about this movie, I was afraid it was a remake of the 1932 classic of the same name, one of my all-time favourite movies. Thankfully, it isn't that at all. This movie is more of an X-Men or Stranger Things or Miss Peregrine's type deal about people with superpowers who are persecuted by normal people who fear them and want to kill them. We've seen this kind of thing before, but the way this movie tells its story was actually really interesting. It throws you into this world and slowly gives you information about what's really going on, like an unfolding mystery. This made for a very engaging and entertaining film. I actually see real franchise potential, there are all sorts of stories that could be told that take place in this world that I would love to see explored, like a low-budget MCU. The performances in this movie are all really good, even the child acting was tolerable! The effects were decent and this movie has a lot of genuinely suspenseful, scary and shocking moments! Definitely check this movie out if you're a fan of stuff like X-Men and want to see a lower-budget, more mature take on it. It's very good!
Even though it was low budget it is still a very inventive and well written movie.

Taking on a well worn mutant story line that's been part of the mighty Marvel universe from day one, where the line between good and bad is hazy grey, "Freaks" is less about showy CGI but more about familial relations. And that's why it works. The daughter, mother, father and grandpa family tree that forms the film is a messy tangle of branches and unwieldy roots, which slowly align as the plot unfolds.

Lexy Kolker as single digit aged Chloe, brings a charming naiveté of someone new to life, who might have access to a mysterious super power. The movie rests on her tiny shoulders, and she pulls it off. Whether dealing with her sketchy dad (Emile Hersh) who may or may not be crazy, or her ghostly mom (Amanda Crew) who may or may not be real, or her sketchy grandpa (Bruce Dern) who may or may not be the neighbourhood ice cream man, Chloe is the central magnet and is damn easy to root for.

Adding another late career feather in his well worn acting hat, Dern is devilicious in his rambunctious retiree role, offering equal doses of creepiness and blood line dedication. Chloe's confusing and changing allegiances to her dad and grandpa is a clever device that spices up this top notch thriller.

My biggest problem with Emile Hirsch is that he looks and acts like Jack Black. It's distracting. But that's a personal qualm, and one that shouldn't detract from the performance, which is manic good.

Yes the story gets a little wacky, after all we are talking about an apocalyptic mutant scenario, so wacky is par for the course. There's enough heart, relatability, and thankfully a lack of superhero posturing (no silly costumes!) to make "Freaks"  a winner.

The sci fi and horror genres are full of bigger budget movies that are polished but emotionally empty. So it's incredibly exciting to see a movie this real and raw, that grabs your guts and pulls you on an emotional rollercoaster. I dove into this little girl's eyes and swam in her soul during the entire film, feeling her fear, her yearning, her anger, and ultimately the love for her family. I cringed at the beginning, I gripped the armrests in the middle, and I cried at the end. Nothing is as it first seems in Freaks... the way the story keeps twisting and turning your expectations and allegiances -- so that you end up loving characters you hated at the start -- is truly unique. A must-see for everyone who loves scifi stories that go a little deeper.

An enjoyable little sci-fi flick that revolves around the stellar performance of young Lexy Kolker. Hey RT. At least give Lexy some love and put her photo on the movie review site. This young actress was the focus of the film in a not terribly original role of an omnipotent child realizing her awesome kick-ass potential but the role was well executed. What made her sympathetic was her longing for her (believed dead) mother and how desperate she was to find a substitute. I did particularly enjoy the part about Dallas being destroyed. That was a nice touch for a Houston boy.

I didn't know much about this film when I went to see it. It took  about 20 minutes for me to warm to it because I wasn't really sure where it was going. It seems like it is one of those small movies that it really good and deserved a bigger release. If you like sci-fi you will probably like this movie.

I have seen the screening of Freaks, it is one of the most enjoyable movies I have seen in a long time. It is refreshing to see a Suspense/thriller movie with a truly original approach, that does not follow tired cliches and tropes that seem to be what movies have become today. Rod Serling would have sat in the theater and wondered what was coming next as I did, the script and film work held me spellbound in my seat. Sets were used at a minimum and I loved the house, there was always something new to spot (such as the writing or drawings on the walls) I would have spent the entire day walking that set just to explore the background. 
This is a must see movie when it is officially released, it will not disappoint
